text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
i'm with a caramel pork belly such a
trendy ingredient you see it on like
every show now and you know i figure
it's about time I did something with it
I found a beautiful piece of pork belly
in Japan town San Francisco it's about a
ten ounce piece of Berkshire pork and if
you're saying it looks like bacon out
same cut its pork belly is bacon that's
cured and smoked so I'm going to take a
piece of heavy-duty aluminum foil I'm
going to put down a little bed of green
onions place my pork down the fattier
side down I'm going to give a little bit
of salt to the meteor side there not too
much the caramel sauce is fairly salty
so just a little sprinkle salt some more
green onions and then I'm going to wrap
this up in a couple layers of aluminum
foil I'm going to press it nice and firm
most of the air out of there all right
so that's one piece wrap it in another
piece and what we're going to do is
we're going to put it in a loaf pan with
a seam side up and we're going to roast
this really slowly in a very very very
slow oven so 200 degrees and we're going
to set our timer for five and a half
hours and after five and a half hours
you're going to turn off the oven and
just leave the pork in there to cool so
it's going to stay in there another
couple hours then you're going to
refrigerate it overnight which is really
crucial it's gotta be completely chilled
before you slice it I'm going to pull
off those green onions and you see
because we cooked it so slowly it really
didn't lose much volume I'm going to cut
it in eight pieces and on a medium heat
then a saute pan I'm going to crisp up
all six sides which takes a little while
but you know what you've already waited
like a day so you know relax enjoy the
ride all right so while that's crisping
up I'm going to get my caramel sauce
ready which is really simple it's kind
of a take on the slanted or caramel
chicken sauce brown sugar rice vinegar
fish sauce you knew that was coming and
a little dash of soy sauce and then I'm
going to grade about a two ounce piece
of ginger squeeze it to get that
beautiful ginger juice and that little
piece of ginger was bugging me so let me
find that get rid of it and you see that
pork how beautifully it's browning I
want to get it all beautifully crispy
and brown
and listen to that how you're not going
to make this after listening to that all
right for my aromatics we have some
sliced garlic some green onions and some
dried red hot fiery hot red chilies
alright once my pork is brown I'm going
to soak up some of the oil and I realize
in some cultures I would be promptly
arrested for doing that but that's okay
I'm going to pull out most of the fat
I'm going to put in one tablespoon of
that glaze i'ma turn the heat up to
medium-high and I just want to
caramelize the edges of that pork first
before I have the rest of the sauce so
just keep turning it
I recommend a freakishly small wooden
spoon for this works very nicely and you
see there as soon as it's glazed on all
sides and that sugar has caramelized and
it's almost getting from dark brown
borderline blackish that is perfect I'm
gonna make a little well in the middle
I'm going to add my aromatic vegetables
the garlic the green onions and the
chilies and we're going to just give
that about a minute saute and then we're
going to add the rest of the ingredients
which is very basic we're going to add a
little bit of water and we're going to
add the rest of our glaze the rest of
our caramel sauce and we're just going
to simmer that until the sauce thickens
a little bit remember the porks cooked
the pork is way cooked so what we're
doing really the pork is flavoring the
sauce the sauce is absorbing all the
flavors from the pork and as soon as
that sauce thickens up like that
our deliciously decadent pork belly is
done
I'd say taste and just seasoning but you
can't because the sauce is very intense
it's salty sweet tangy spicy but the
reason for that is I'm going to serve
this on some fairly bland brown rice
that I cooked with some bok choy so when
you eat the rich pork and you break it
apart and eat it with that rice and bok
choy the intense sauce really works
perfectly together
this is one of the most delicious things
I've eaten in months
and I hope you try it get a small piece
of pork belly you don't need much a
little bit goes a long way and give that
a try all the ingredients are on the
site and as always enjoy
